text: probably about two and a half to three
hours after I'd initially felt the first
sensation I was no longer able to walk I
was no longer able to stand my left side
was very much but numb without much
feeling I didn't have much control of my
fingers on my left hand and I was then
told that yeah I had suffered a stroke
[Music]
initially there was obviously fear and
just sort of okay you know what's my
life gonna be like from this point on am
I going to be what's up what sort of
mobility am I gonna have our lack of
mobility is my family gonna have to take
care of me am I gonna be able to dress
myself you know all sorts of things you
know sort of go through your mind at
that point it's it's very scary
the doctors told me that you know your
best chance for any stroke victim the
best chance for recovery is to
immediately get into physical therapy so
I was two days later I was allowed to
start physical therapy ironically that
first walk was about 200 meters which is
the event that I you know held the world
record at and was once the fastest man
in the world in in history at that event
and it took about 15 minutes for me to
cover that 200 meters and you know
ordinarily I'm sure that you know anyone
in that situation would be disappointed
and and but I wasn't I was actually
encouraged and it's what encouraged me
because with every step I could
experience and feel some very tiny and
it's very small incremental improvements
and as a sprinter where you know the
wins and losses can be measured in
hundreds and thousands of seconds and
you're dealing with you know tiny tiny
incremental improvements every day I
could recognize that and and I kept back
to my room and I said to my wife I'm
gonna make a full recovery I'm sure of
it and I'm gonna make this recovery
faster than anyone has ever done it
